Squad does not implement the concept of links as the rest of the world comprehends. They rely on the community (us) to post the links into this community hub.

I don't like it, but that is the reality.

(not related... I see GOG has the Empire Earth series for sale - many good times playing that with friends all over the world)

I've purchased a lot of old games from them and am in general quite satisfied with the setup. This sounds like a reasonable move that could bring KSP to a lot more players, and it's always nice to have another non-Steam option.

P.S. They have Alpha Centauri and Master of Orion II. You know what you have to do.

This IMHO is an example of \*why\* Squad are badging the upcoming update 1.0. Not because the update is particularly significant on its own merits (though it \*is\* a fairly large one) but because they want to cast off that alpha/beta label in order to sell KSP in more places.

> 
> This IMHO is an example of \*why\* Squad are badging the upcoming update 1.0. Not because the update is particularly significant on its own merits (though it \*is\* a fairly large one) but because they want to cast off that alpha/beta label in order to sell KSP in more places.

Selling in places more than steam isn't significant in any way. I love that they bring it to GoG, but it won't bring them too much in terms of sales.

Sometimes the obvious answer is closer to the truth than conspiracy theories.^^

> hmm. So like.. they took games from old OS's, such as windows 98, windows 2000, XP, and make them work on modern systems?

Also DOS. But 2000/XP are actually basically the same as "modern" windows, FYI. They're all part of the NT family and most of the changes have been largely cosmetic (desktop) or stupid (desktop, SxS), or very minor and could have easily been backported (4Kn support, DX9/10/11, etc).

The value in their services primarily lies in the DOS/95/98/ME games, as there's significant differences between the '95 family and NT family, and well, obviously even bigger differences between the DOS family and NT family. Games written for NT4/2K/XP should still work under Vista/7/8 if written properly - I have some old DirectX3 (yes, THREE) games I scribbled up that still work under Win7 for instance. However, most programmers are ScrubLords of the Isle of Idiocy and Reading Comprehension Fail and couldn't read system documentation and understand forward compatibility to save their life.

(As an example, Microsoft specifically warned in the early DirectDraw surface documentation that the stride may not equal the width of the display in future versions of video cards and drivers, and sure enough, they don't)

> I've purchased a lot of old games from them and am in general quite satisfied with the setup. This sounds like a reasonable move that could bring KSP to a lot more players, and it's always nice to have another non-Steam option.
